prompt: If the distance between Earth and the Sun were suddenly doubled, the gravitational attraction between the two bodies would:
description: Newton's Law of Gravitation states that the gravitational attraction between two bodies is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. Mathematically, the law is stated this way: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi>m1</mi><mi>m2</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math>, where G is a constant, m1 and m2 are the masses of the two bodies, and r is the distance between the two bodies.
feedback: If the distance, r, between the two bodies doubles, then the gravitational attraction between them decreases by 1 over 22, or 1/4.
